I remember there was a State Farm case that developed these guideposts to determine whether punitive damages were excessive, the guideposts themselves were developed in an earlier BMW case: (1) degree of reprehensibility of Dfs conduct; (2) ratio b/n punitive, harm likely to result, harm that actually occurred; (3) civil/criminal penalties that could be imposed for comparable misconduct.
The reprehensibility factor is the most significant. Only the reprehensible conduct that is closely related to the plaintiffs particular harm. - the most important factor - State Farm Considered: (i) whether the harm caused was physical as opposed to economic; (ii) the conduct showed an indifference to or reckless disregard to the health/safety of others; (iii) the target had financial vulnerability; (iv) actions were isolated or repeated; (v) harm resulted from intentional malice, trickery or mere accident.
...those are a snip-it of my notes. We obviously don't have all the facts, but it sounds like this guy does this quite often by the way Fieger responds to some of the questioning. Maybe they are going with the 3rd guidepost by showing that is the value of Mike's license? Shot in the dark...I'm sure there was a lot of weighing the facts to come to a number like that.

Here in Michigan you can get treble damages (x3) for Conversion, but this isn't conversion. You could file a suit in small claims court under a breach of contract principle for misrepresentation. Article 2 of the UCC would apply because they are in the business of selling goods, and therefore from purchasing the good you have a reasonable time to inspect and reject the good if it does not satisfy your reason for purchasing it under whats called the [perfect tender rule](https://www.google.com/search?q=perfect+tender+rule rlz=1C1CHZL_enUS687US687 oq=perfect+tender+rule aqs=chrome..69i57j0l5.2905j0j7 sourceid=chrome ie=UTF-8).

WRITING.TITLE: Time Machine: Where would you go? What would you do?
WRITING.TEXT:
I know there are somewhat similar questions in this subs history, but I'd like to have a frank conversation with anyone who would indulge in submitting a response to this post.
I always told myself, I'd want to see it all, but was naive and shook my head thinking, you'll never have enough *time* to *see it all*. Clearly my mind was closed off to the fact...I have a *time machine* and I would be capable of seeing it all!
Take out the security issues, landing logistics, and step onto the Ship of Imagination.
I'm fascinated with animals that are extinct or on the verge of going on extinct. I would start my quest with cataloging EVERY SINGLE, and I mean it, every form of life to have ever been present on this planet. I think that would be one of the most fascinating things.
Once I completed that journey, I think I would go visit the Grand Canyon, Niagara Falls, and the Great Lakes to watch them form frame by frame. Maybe go to the Yucatan and watch the [Chicxulub Crater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicxulub_crater) form.
That would be just the start of my journey through time and space.

People are busy, they don't want someone who is going to sit back and trust someone is going to read something, they want a fucking hustler, someone who is going to go out and get shit done.
I'd suggest finding the firm you would like to work for, doing research on them to determine who the correct person to talk with, and then reaching out to that person for 5min of their time. It becomes easier when you have met this person or you have some type of in-office connection.
Things will work out, but you have to put yourself in the best position for it to do so.

Partly correct.
Take out the SJ concept for right now, that is a different subject and you can make the connection later.
The Plaintiff has the burden to established that the Defendant owed them a duty, the defendant breached that duty owed to the plaintiff, the defendant was the causation (cause in fact/actual cause), and the plaintiff suffered damages resulting from the defendant breach of their duty.
The evidence part comes with showing the defendant acted negligently, the causation portion of the prima facia negligence analysis.

YEAAAA, I loved that absurd Palsgraf case; reminded me of the Mousetrap game.
Dude, I would ask the prof. I can almost guarantee that Prima Facia *IS STILL RELEVANT* because I just went over it in my bar prep and had almost my entire torts two class about it back in LS.
Statute = Negligence Per Se...NOTHING ELSE. Prima Facia Negligence will have a person, most likely a professional or someone to whom you've had a case set out some type of duty of care required, and they will usually fail to act or at in a way that is inadequate in reference to their required duty. Ex. would be if you cause someone to be in peril, you have a duty to attempt to rescue them, if you just sit and watch the house burn down after you set it on fire knowing there was sleeping babies in the house...you failed to act and therefore you would be negligent in the event the suffered damages...super absurd example, but you will remember it. There are different standard of care each person owes another given the individuals position; usually its going to be reasonable care, but most professionals are held to a higher standard of care. Standard of care = the duty owed to another.
Yup, those are it. Thank you!

Right, thanks again for the response!
I guess I'm having trouble following all these "creative avenues" because there are so many of them. Essentially my goals would be able to talk to someone, who we'd eventually have in-house, who would be out web developer.
Maybe I need to find someone now on the ground level to let them in on the beginning so they can scale the business with us so we don't have to pay someone max price one we finally start operating. But, my goals, yeah-my goals would be to essentially be able to talk to the client about what we can offer with regard to their law firm.
The traditional law firm scheme doesn't work in my opinion and because of ethical rules attorneys are bound by in each state it is somewhat difficult to market to your prospective clients. I want to design a best practices of law firms that is almost a guerrilla style marketing scheme to put them in front of as many people I can.
Also with the SEO, I'm putting off writing it because all these little tricks you can use with the langugage when you write it make a big difference says everything I read on the internet. (Yes, everything is not true, but a lot of it is and I don't know if it's not)
TLDR: In a nutshell I should develop my own law firm strategy and bundle what works into something scale-able to sell.

* (1) Not always a safety statute, but a statute indeed. The most common example you'll see if the violation of some type of moving offense. The key to look out for is the defendant MUST be doing *EXACTLY* what the statue outlaws. I had bar prep and one of the examples was a trick where the statute was that it was illegal to text/use mobile phone while driving. The defendant was on their phone at a red light, they were subsequently pulled over and given a ticket...they were NOT using the mobile phone *while driving,* so it was NOT negligence per se.
* (2) Id have to see the case. Can you rephrase your question, I don't know what your asking; it may be beyond my negligence expertise.
* (3) Remember to keep these things COMPLETELY SEPARATE from one another. Res Ispa does not need actual evidence, it means "the thing speaks for itself," There is a rebuttable presumption that the defendant was the one who is negligent because of (insert factors and analysis). If the defendant can provide enough evidence to overturn that presumption, they are going to be found not guilty. Prima Facie Negligence your going to get into a deep delving into actual evidence of proving each facet required. Duty, you must established there is a duty, if there is no duty then there is an irrebutable presumption there could be no prima facia negligence against the plaintiff-motion for summary disposition, boom judge rules in your favor absent plaintiff provides sufficient evidence. In that instance you could even go with a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim upon relief could be granted because the plaintiff did not satisfy their initial burden of establishing a duty. Best advice I could give you is to learn how these things work individually, and then learn how you can mish mash them a get them to work together...that's lawyering. Just like any other law suit this is going to go through the correct court with property jurisdiction (personal, subject matter, and venue), while utilizing the many tools at an Attorneys' fingertips to attempt to get it tossed out or ruled in their favor.
* NO QUESTION IS EVER STUPID, seriously, I EMPHASIZE FOR A REASON! If you don't ask questions, then your not learning. Your, assuming you are, paying a lot of money to go to law school...do it right the first time. Ask questions, rephrase, reconsider, re-ask! Don't be shy.
Um, I had my torts prof. tell us this shit was no big deal...come final time, it was all negligence. On the MBE, something like 20 out of the 27/8 torts questions will be on negligence. You need to know negligence, absolute period.

* Negligence Per Se: Your driving down the street *over the speed limit* and your pulled over and given a ticket. You violated the statute, you were negligent in monitoring your speed, thus you were negligent. Statute must be involved.
* Prima Facie Negligence: Duty, Breach, Causation (Cause in fact/actual cause), and Damages. There must be an established *DUTY.*
* Res Ipsa Loquitor: Barrel falls out of a barrel warehouse window. No direct evidence that the barrel warehouse was at fault, but there are no other barrel warehouses in the city. There are 3 requirements for this one you have to meet I think, maybe two, I can't remember. (1) Defendant must be in control of the instrumentality...I know that's one. There is no direct evidence linking the Defendant to the damages, but it was them, they were the ones who did it...everyone knows.
*Sorry at work, otherwise I'd give you a more in depth analysis*
This is an open-source response, someone polish it up. haha

We have talked about opening up a marketing firm specifically tailored to law firms in our home state. Where we are from, there are hundreds if not thousands of law firms that do not have any direction with how they market their business. Many of the firms don't have mobile optimized websites, some have broken links all over their websites, some have websites that just dump information because they think its a good "blog topic" and go on and on...etc. He has worked at a law firm, and with me soon to be an Attorney, our thought was to leverage my knowledge of the legal field and his marketing background to form a marketing company geared specifically to law firms.
I may be taking on too much at once, but that's just how my brain works. My main focus is obtaining the license to practice law, and then I feel everything will fall into place.
Edit: A set of best practices would be nice, but it doesn't seem that cut and dry anymore. This SEO shit has got me all confused, it's so fluid it's annoying. I've read you should string keywords, then read not to string keywords, just as an example. I guess I'm subconsciously attempting to sift through all this bs to develop a best practice for law firms.

Under the US Constitution Congress is free to regulate commerce under the Commerce Clause. Absent Congressional regulation, States are free to regulate, as long as the State's Regulation *DOES NOT* unduly burden and discriminate against interstate commerce. "Dormant" refers to the absence of Federal Regulation.
* In the absence of Federal Regulation, State Regulation of commerce is *PRESUMED* valid if:
* (1) There is *NO* discrimination against out-of-state "interests;" * (2) The regulation *DOES NOT* unduly burden interstate commerce; AND * (3) The regulation *DOES NOT* apply to wholly extraterritorial activity.
You must analysis all three of these elements to outweigh the presumption that the state regulation is constitutional and thus violates the Dormant Commerce Clause.
* (1) No Discrimination against out-of-state interests (*Most Important Factor*): Applied to both business and personal interest. Discrimination exists if state/local regulation protects local economic interest--*at the expense of out-of-state competition.* * There are 3 exceptions to this though: (1) State as Market Participant; (2) State Subsidy/Welfare to State only citizens; and (3) Federal Approval/Ratification of the States' regulation.
* (2) No Undue Burden on Interstate Commerce: You must balance objective/purpose of the State law vs. the burden on interstate commerce; ie. Is there a less restrictive alternative? If the State law benefits are grossly outweighed by the burden on interstate commerce--it's likely the courts will strike down the regulation as unconstitutional.
* (3) Extraterritorial: States *CANNOT* regulate conduct that occurs wholly *BEYOND* their borders.

WRITING.TITLE: Listen ABA Journal, I know, how do we fix this?

WRITING.TEXT:
I know more than 10 police officers who have professional-side jobs. One of them flips houses regularly, and currently is renting out 10 houses at the tune of $1000/mo per house. Another owns a PI Firm and contracts with local PI/No-Fault law firms and does surveillance and process serving. Another, owns a website-marketing business. Another, does private security on the side.
The fact is...if you can achieve a $90,000 core salary, you can easily supplement your salary over a extended period of time by building your solo network up as you go. You don't have to take on criminal cases, but you can do transactional work to generate a lot of income. As a police officer your going to have an extensive network.
I've thought about this exact scenario as well. I have a BA in criminal justice and over five years of private security experience; add the JD in the mix and I'm a shoe in to any department around me. I went to law school to get away from the criminal justice system, so that's my reason to forgo a PO position. Someone has posted on here that you going to have to answer a lot of questions for a while, but that isn't that hard; just site this article [Here](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/lawyers_salaries_slipping_compared_to_other_professions_data_indicates/?utm_source=maestro utm_medium=email utm_campaign=weekly_email).
Moral of the story is...this is your story, and everything from this EXACT^exact second is unwritten..write what you want to live! Good luck.

10,000% this!
I don't know what his student loan status is, but you could also take advantage of the PSLF program.

If your arguing that the legislation infringes upon a fundamental right, your going to use the strict scrutiny analysis. The government has the burden to show that the law is necessary to achieve a compelling government interest. The law must be the least restrictive means to achieve the compelling government interest. "Least restrictive" means that there cannot be a way to achieve the same interest that is less restrictive. The law should be neither over-inclusive nor under-inclusive. "Compelling interest" has no definition, but must be necessary and crucial to national security, health, and/or safety.
Now, if the same legislation also effects a classification of persons, then EPC will apply as well--but in a stand-alone analysis.
You should read your facts SUPER^super carefully. Even if it doesn't call for it, don't forget to address Standing, Ripeness, and Mootness. If you have something canned in your head, you should be able to jot it down right quick to show your prof your train of thought; this will almost always give you deference because they will know you know what your talking about.
